sentence.text: The propositus was born to an 18-year-old woman and a 23-year-old man.
He was born at 33 weeks of gestation by a normal vaginal delivery, with a birth weight of 1,814 g (10–25th centile) and a length of 40.6 cm (3rd–10th centile).
He began walking at 15 months.
He had difficulty in rising from a sitting position and performed a Gower maneuver when attempting to stand.
He walked with a wide-based gait and often complained of leg pains.
At age 4 years, he was at the 25th centile for height and the 20th centile for weight.
He had lumbar lordosis, decreased reflexes, generalized weakness, and right cryptorchidism.
Biopsies of the right and left gastrocnemius by report showed muscle bundles with some variation in staining reaction.
The pale staining areas had poor definition of fibers, granularity, and fibrillation.
He was diagnosed with pseudohypertrophic muscular dystrophy.
He continued with the diagnosis of muscular dystrophy until age 17 years when a maternal aunt was diagnosed with PDD.
He was unable to run and could only lift 5 pounds with each arm.
He was pale and extremely thin.
The shafts of his long bones were thickened.
He had limited mobility at the shoulders, elbows, knees and hips, lumbar lordosis, genua valga, pronated flat feet, a wide-based, waddling gait, and poor muscular development.
The skin over the tibiae was tightly stretched and shiny.
He had hyperhidrosis of hands and feet, and delayed sexual maturation.
Radiographs showed cortical thickening of the diaphyses of the femora, tibiae, fibulae, humeri, radii, and ulnae with narrowed medullary cavities.
The metaphyses and epiphyses were normal.
The skull showed thickening of the roofs of the orbits and the medial portion of the petrous bones.
The bones of the hands and feet, pelvis, vertebrae, ribs, and clavicles were normal.
Bone age was determined to be 12½ years at age 17 years.
At age 18 years, he was 152 cm tall and weighed 32 kg.
His linear growth began to accelerate at age 22.
At age 25 years he reached 183 cm in height.
At age 29 years he reported cold intolerance.
He had cyanosis of nail beds, pectus excavatum, and cubitus valgus bilaterally.
He now had markedly hyperactive deep tendon reflexes with otherwise normal neurological findings.
He began taking cortisone at age 30 years.
This resulted in a significant decrease in lower limb pain and fatigue.
His muscle bulk and strength increased.
At age 46 years, he presented with bilateral hip pain and decreased range of motion.
Radiographs showed avascular necrosis of the femoral heads and bilateral acetabular dysplasia.
He underwent bilateral hip surface replacements.
He began having neck pain with limited range of motion of the cervical spine.
Radiographs showed extensive spondylosis involving C4-5, C5-6, and C6-7.
At age 56 years radiographs of the hips showed increasing resorption of the femoral neck.
He underwent bilateral total hip replacements.
He continued to have good muscle strength and endurance with daily cortisone therapy.
